_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. THE FACILITY POLICY

                  

The owners, management, and the employees of the Progressive Ag Coop are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any releases and minimize the impact of the release to the people and the environment.  Our employees are trained on  a three year, rotating basis.  These meetings are put on annually by the Kansas Department of Ag and KARA (Kansas Agribuisness and Retailers Assoc.).  Employees are trained on chemical properties, safe handling, and safe maintenance procedures.



 2. FACILITY INFORMATION

 

The primary activity at the facility is the storing of fertilizer for sale to the farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients.



The maximum quantity stored would be 192,236 pounds in our tanks with         

one of 26,000 gallons and one of 18,000 gallons. There are 3 nurse tanks on site with a combined capacity of 13,107 pounds.  The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a rail tank car holding 150,000 pounds.



3. WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO



The Worst case and Alternative release scenarios have been removed at the request of the EPA.  This is a security issue and is dictated by the homeland security act.



4. THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PROGRAM 

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia,K-61.1", published by the American Standards Institiute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S.Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia".



Note:  The Kansas Department of Agriculture has not yet adopted the most recent ANSI standards.  However, this company recognizes the importance of meeting the current

standards and will bring all facilities up to the current standard as time and budget allow.



5. THE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past

five years that:

-have caused any deaths, injuries, or other significant property damage at the facility;                    

 nor

 -to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in 

place property damage, or environmental damage.



6. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has: 

-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38

-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right to 

know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)

-a writtten emergency action program in accordance with the

OSHA standard, 29 CFR1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee

training.



7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an ongoing process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of the safe conditions. There are improvements scheduled including emergency shut off valves and break away valves.
